channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin’s Next Move on Ukraine Is a Mystery. Just the Way He Likes It.
item.description: The contradictory, sometimes menacing messages from the Kremlin have stumped Western officials and Russia experts, showing the Russian leader’s desire to keep his rivals on edge.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:description: A state-media photo of President Vladimir V. Putin at the Defence Ministry in Moscow in December.

item.title: A Russian Pledge of No Invasion? Ukrainians Are Skeptical.
item.description: When Russians say no, they often mean yes, a former Ukrainian member of Parliament said, as suspicion ran deep about Moscow’s intentions.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian Military Forces serviceman waited on Tuesday at his position on the frontline, near the city of Luhansk, in the Donetsk region.

item.title: Boris Johnson Again Accused of Breaking His Own Lockdown Rules
item.description: The prime minister and his government are accused — yet again — of violating their own lockdown rules, undermining their credibility and attempts to pivot to other issues.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain leaving a vaccination center at a pharmacy in his constituency, Uxbridge, in London, on Monday.

item.title: Source of Mysterious Gas Leak Explosion in Canadian Town Stumps Officials
item.description: An explosion last summer in an Ontario community built on 19th-century gas wells has left locals searching for answers and some certainty that their town will ever recover.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Wheatley, Ontario, where a large gas explosion last August destroyed three buildings.

item.title: How the ‘Djokovic Affair’ Came Back to Bite Australia’s Prime Minister
item.description: Scott Morrison thought he had a political winner. Now, with an election looming, Australians debate their government’s fairness and competence.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia used the news about Novak Djokovic’s visa to return to a well-tested tactic: stirring voter support with appeals to tough border enforcement.

item.title: Novak Djokovic Tested Positive: A Timeline of What Happened Next
item.description: If a tennis star knew he was positive for the coronavirus, why did he keep making public appearances without a mask?
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das

item.title: Over Half of Europe Could Be Infected With Coronavirus Soon, W.H.O. Says
item.description: The agency cautioned against treating the virus like the seasonal flu, since much remains unknown, particularly regarding the severity in areas with lower vaccination rates.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A line for coronavirus tests in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: Can Russia Be Stopped From Invading Ukraine? Here's What We Know
item.description: The United States, its NATO allies and Russia meet this week in a whirlwind of diplomacy aimed at averting the largest military action in Europe since World War II. Here’s a guide to what’s at stake.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier patrolling the front lines in Avdiivka, Ukraine, on Dec. 2. Tensions between Ukraine and Russia have been simmering since 2014.

item.title: Kazakhstan Says Russian Troops Can Start Leaving This Week
item.description: Kazakhstan’s president says violence has been quelled, so there is no longer need for the foreign troops he asked to help. Russia has not given a timeline for withdrawing.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A building that was torched during recent unrest in Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Tuesday.

item.title: How the Kazakhstan Protests Started and Why They Matter
item.description: As protests in the oil-rich Central Asian country gain momentum, the events threaten to reverberate across the region.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Riot police during a protest on Wednesday over an increase in energy prices in Almaty, Kazakhstan.

item.title: On Day Biden Calls Ethiopia’s Leader to Urge Peace, a Drone Strike Kills 17
item.description: The attack came days after over 50 people were killed in a strike on a refugee camp, highlighting the growing role of armed drones in a destructive war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Survivors of an air strike by Ethiopian government forces at a hospital in the town of Dedebit, in the northern region of Tigray, Ethiopia, on Saturday.

item.title: Freelance Reporter for the New York Times Is On Trial in Zimbabwe
item.description: The reporter, Jeffrey Moyo, has been accused of helping two Times journalists enter Zimbabwe from South Africa using bogus credentials, a charge that even the government admits is on ‘shaky ground.’
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeffrey Moyo, second from left, conferring with his lawyers, Doug Coltart and Beatrice Mtetwa, outside the courtroom in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, on Tuesday, as Mr. Moyo’s wife, Purity, second from right, listens. Mr. Moyo’s trial begins on Wednesday.

item.title: Suspect in South Africa’s Parliament Fire Is Sent for Psychiatric Check
item.description: If the man is found fit to stand trial, he will face charges that now include terrorism. His lawyers said he would protest with a hunger strike.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Zandile Christmas Mafe, who is suspected of setting the fire that tore through South Africa’s Parliament buildings, appeared in court in Cape Town on Tuesday.

item.title: European Parliament's President, David Sassoli, Dies at 65
item.description: He was a well-known journalist in his native Italy before going into politics, and devoted his tenure to making the Parliament more prominent.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: David Sassoli, president of the European Parliament, during the opening of a plenary session in Strasbourg, France, last year.

item.title: Shirley McGreal, Champion of Primates Under Threat, Dies at 87
item.description: She exposed smuggling rings and research laboratories and built a sanctuary for gibbons in South Carolina.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Omicron in Europe
item.description: “A closing window to act,” said the W.H.O.’s Europe director.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: “For countries not yet hit with the omicron surge, there is a closing window to act now,” said Dr. Hans Kluge, the W.H.O. Europe director.

item.title: Magawa, Hero Rat That Hunted Land Mines, Dies in Retirement
item.description: The African giant pouched rat sniffed out more than 100 mines and other pieces of unexploded ordnance in Cambodia over five years, winning hearts and an international award.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien
item.media:description: Magawa with his handler last year in Siem Reap, Cambodia.

item.title: San Francisco Ballet Appoints Tamara Rojo to Artistic Director
item.description: Rojo, who has given the English National Ballet a new allure, succeeds Helgi Tomasson as just the fifth director to lead the San Francisco company.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas
item.media:credit: Kalpesh Lathigra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tamara Rojo will succeed Helgi Tomasson as the artistic director of San Francisco Ballet.

item.title: Dorms Pop Up in Spain as More Students Seek Housing Away From Home
item.description: The country’s student population has become increasingly mobile, fueling investments in accommodations, largely funded by foreign capital.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brian Dervishi, an Italian student, in a studio he rents in the Livensa Living student dorm in Málaga, Spain.

item.title: A Growing Gap Between the Vaccinated and Unvaccinated
item.description: We look at Omicron’s toll in New York and Seattle, two cities with timely data.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Covid testing in Brooklyn.

item.title: In South Africa, Success Against H.I.V. Offers Hope
item.description: A former Africa correspondent, who covered the height of the AIDS epidemic there 15 years ago, finds lessons in the remarkable progress against that virus for our current fight.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A near-empty ward of the Chongwe District Hospital outside Lusaka, Zambia. Fifteen years ago, a hospital like this would have been overflowing with H.I.V. patients lying two or three to a bed.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A groundbreaking medical procedure.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: U.N. Seeks Huge Aid Increase to Prevent ‘Catastrophe’ in Afghanistan
item.description: The $5 billion appeal comes as a severe drought and the toll of decades of war have plunged three-quarters of the country’s population into acute poverty, according to the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A child suffering from severe malnutrition at the Indira Gandhi Children’s Hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, in October.

item.title: In Talks on Ukraine, U.S. and Russia Deadlock Over NATO Expansion
item.description: Both sides expressed some optimism after negotiations in Geneva, but did not break an impasse over Russia’s demand that Ukraine never become a member of NATO.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The American delegation, left, and its Russian counterparts as they met in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: North Korea Launches 2nd Ballistic Missile in a Week, South Korea Says
item.description: The launch came as the U.N. Security Council met to discuss the country’s growing weapons threat. The U.S. said the latest test “highlights the destabilizing impact” of the North’s weapons program.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A television at a Seoul railroad station on Tuesday showed file footage of a North Korean missile test.

item.title: Russia Positioning Helicopters, in Possible Sign of Ukraine Plans
item.description: The step, which could be an indication that planning for an attack continues, comes as the number of Russian troops at the border has remained steady in recent weeks, despite U.S. expectations of a surge.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Russian troops near Ukraine in December. U.S. officials say Moscow’s window for an invasion is limited.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Plays Down Invasion Threat
item.description: The U.S. called some demands “non-starters.”
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman, left, and Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov attended security talks at the United States Mission in Geneva, Switzerland on Monday.

item.title: Nearly 5 Years After Grenfell Fire, U.K. Tells Developers to Pay for Upgrades
item.description: After a deadly high-rise blaze in 2017, countless instances of unsafe building practices came to light. The latest plan to address them expands who will be covered.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Grenfell Tower, a high-rise residential building in London, now stands covered in what the government calls a “protective wrapping.”

item.title: Haitian Prime Minister Had Close Links With Murder Suspect
item.description: New evidence suggests the man who took over from Haiti’s murdered president had close links to a prime suspect in the assassination — and that the two stayed in contact even after the crime.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jovenel Moïse, who was assassinated in July, led Haiti by decree and turned to authoritarian tactics.

item.title: Famed White Cliffs of Sicily Are Defaced in an Act of Vandalism
item.description: Vandals stained a cliff formation known as the Staircase of the Turks with red splotches over the weekend. Residents of a nearby town banded together for a successful cleanup.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The Scala dei Turchi in Realmonte, Italy, on Saturday, before the cleanup.

item.title: Crashed Pilot Is Pulled to Safety Seconds Before Train Plows Through
item.description: Los Angeles police officers pulled the pilot of a small plane away from the tracks moments before a train smashed into it at high speed.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Claire Fahy
item.media:description: A still from bodycam footage shows a crashed plane moments before a train hit the wreckage in Los Angeles on Sunday.

item.title: In India, Mask Wearing Is Down Despite Rising Coronavirus Cases
item.description: Health officials are finding it harder to impose regulations despite signs that Omicron is beginning to take hold.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Police officers dispersing beachgoers in Mumbai on Sunday to enforce Covid restrictions.

item.title: China’s Covid Outbreak Complicates Safety Plan for Beijing Olympics
item.description: Officials are racing to extinguish a spate of coronavirus infections around the country.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:description: Members of a disinfection team at the press center for the Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics on Monday.

item.title: Russian Troops Will Stay to Finish Job in Kazakhstan, Putin Says
item.description: Blaming “internal and external forces” for the unrest in the resource-rich Central Asian country, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia set no deadline for the withdrawal of the forces his country sent there.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia joined a meeting of the Collective Security Treaty Organization, a body akin to NATO, via video conference on Monday.

item.title: Holding Pundits Accountable for Covid and Inflation
item.description: Writers and experts should be transparent about what they got wrong.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Covid testing in Houston.

item.title: U.S.-Russia Talks Have Echoes of the Cold War
item.description: The Cold War echoes of the negotiations unfolding this week in a series of meetings between Russia and the West are a reminder that there is nothing permanent about Europe’s security arrangements.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Russian tactical combat exercises in the Rostov region, east of Ukraine, in December.

item.title: The Biden administration gave a preview of how it would punish Russia if it invaded Ukraine.
item.description: Such moves are rarely telegraphed in advance, but advisers say they are hoping to influence the decisions of Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Russian troops during military exercises in December.

item.title: Uganda Reopens Schools After World’s Longest Covid Shutdown
item.description: Many countries have closed classrooms on and off, but Uganda had kept more than 10 million students at home since March 2020. Critics say it took a heavy toll.
item.dc:creator: Musinguzi Blanshe and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children back in class at Kitante Primary School in Kampala, Uganda, on Monday.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Will Discuss European Security, but Without Europeans
item.description: The coming talks in Geneva are bilateral, reviving old fears that the two Cold War powers will forge a deal on their own.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ukrainian reservists taking part in a military exercise last month near Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: As Its Population Soars to 40, Rum Isle Glimpses a Future in the Mist
item.description: With four new families recently arriving, the remote and rainy island in the Hebrides is experiencing its version of a population surge, although residents new and old concede living here isn’t easy.

item.title: In Myanmar, Aung San Suu Kyi Sentenced to 4 More Years
item.description: Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader was convicted on three more counts under Covid and telecommunications rules, which her defenders said were politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in 2015. She was sentenced in Myanmar on Monday to four years in prison for possessing walkie-talkies in her home and for violating Covid-19 protocols.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Key diplomatic talks about Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Russian deputy foreign minister, Sergei A. Ryabkov, in June. He will meet with U.S. negotiators in talks aimed at de-escalating tensions on Ukraine.

item.title: Novak Djokovic Can Remain in Australia, Judge Rules
item.description: Australian officials hinted they may make a new attempt to cancel Djokovic’s visa, even as the tennis champion, freed from detention, returned to the court.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Matthew Futterman
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic before a Davis Cup match in Austria last year.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Djokovic’s Appeal to Australia
item.description: Plus violence in Kazakhstan and the release of an imprisoned Saudi princess from jail.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Srdjan Stevanovic/Euroleague Basketball via Getty Images
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic is in quarantine in Australia, awaiting a hearing on his appeal of the government’s decision.

item.title: James A. Baker III’s Words on NATO Loom in Ukraine Standoff
item.description: The current confrontation turns partly on what, if any, commitments Secretary of State James A. Baker III made about NATO’s expansion in the waning days of the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Michael Temchine for The New York Times
item.media:description: James A. Baker III has said that in the end, he did not rule out NATO expansion into Eastern Europe in a treaty signed after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

item.title: Cliff Collapses on Boaters in Brazil, Killing 10
item.description: The tragedy in Minas Gerais state gripped the nation because it was captured on videos that showed an immense slab of rock smashing into pleasure boats.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: A canyon in Lake Furnas, near Capitólio in southeast Brazil.

item.title: Nearly 6,000 Detained Amid Unrest in Kazakhstan
item.description: Protests that began last weekend over a hike in fuel prices spread across the country, leaving at least 2,000 injured, government officials said. Dozens of deaths also appeared likely.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The mayor’s office building was burned during demonstrations last week in Almaty, Kazakhstan.

item.title: Tianjin, a city of 14 million near Beijing, starts testing all residents after Omicron surfaces.
item.description: The city also announced a raft of restrictions in an effort to contain the outbreak and trace its source.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A testing site in Tianjin, China, on Sunday.

item.title: Russia and U.S. Meet to Begin Negotiations Over Ukraine
item.description: Before the two countries met amid rising tensions over Ukraine, a senior Russian official and the U.S. secretary of state set a pessimistic tone.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The Russian deputy foreign minister, Sergei A. Ryabkov, in June. He will meet with U.S. negotiators in talks aimed at de-escalating tensions on Ukraine.

item.title: Saudi Princess Is Released, but Other Royals Are Still Locked Up
item.description: The Saudi government has not said why it detained or freed Princess Basmah bint Saud, a daughter of a former king who has criticized the country’s policies.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Basmah bint Saud, Princess of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: Princess Basmah bint Saud in Washington in 2017 during a discussion about the role of women in the Middle East.

item.title: Hong Kong Party Angers a City Under Covid Controls
item.description: Just as new restrictions were being imposed, top politicians were found to have attended a large gathering where at least one person had Covid.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A line for coronavirus testing on Sunday at Victoria Park in Hong Kong.

item.title: London Schools Are Determined to Stay Open. Staff Illnesses Make It Hard.
item.description: Schools across England are grappling with what it looks like to live with the pandemic as it enters its third year. Sound familiar?
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A science class at Copthall School in North London. Many parents and school administrators are desperate to keep schools open after two years of chaotic closings, but the latest wave of the pandemic has made it difficult.

item.title: As Russia and U.S. Debate Ukraine, Ukraine Would Like a Say
item.description: While the United States and NATO speak with Russia this week, the Ukrainian government has been sidelined and is instead quietly pursuing separate negotiations with Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian reservists during exercises last month near Kyiv, the capital.

item.title: As U.S. Figure Skaters Test Positive, New Worries for Winter Olympics
item.description: Problems at the national championships could turn up in Beijing next month, too.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Thomas
item.media:description: Mariah Bell’s victory at the U.S. national championships on Friday secured her a spot on the American Olympic team.

item.title: Is ‘forever boosting’ in our future? And will that beat the coronavirus?
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Preparing a booster shot of a coronavirus vaccine at a medical center near Tel Aviv in December.

item.title: Chinese Activists Face Subversion Charges for Weekend Gathering
item.description: A weekend get-together in 2019 offered Beijing a chance to deliver a blow to the “rights defense” movement. Now, two key participants face the prospect of years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Allison Zaucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Sifang at home in Los Angeles this month. Mr. Liu was among those who gathered in Xiamen, China, in late 2019 and discussed human rights. He later fled China.

item.title: Chicago's Mayor Rejects Union's Terms for Returning to School
item.description: The standoff between educators and the city’s government shows no signs of abating.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Lori Lightfoot at the police headquarters in Chicago on Tuesday. “Students need to be back” in the classroom, she said on Saturday.

item.title: Scattered protests against pandemic policies pop up in Europe.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
